One of the key strengths of transformers is their ability to capture long-range dependencies within a sequence. This is achieved through the use of self-attention mechanisms, which allow the model to understand the relationships between different parts of the input sequence. This is in contrast to traditional recurrent neural networks, which are limited in their ability to capture long-range dependencies due to the vanishing gradient problem.

Transformers are also highly parallelizable, which makes them suitable for training on large datasets using distributed computing resources. This has led to the development of increasingly powerful transformer models, such as Google's T5 and OpenAI's GPT-3. These models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on a wide range of NLP tasks.

Overall, transformers are a highly effective neural network architecture for a wide range of NLP tasks. Their ability to capture long-range dependencies and their high degree of parallelism make them well-suited for training on large datasets and achieving state-of-the-art performance.
